1.content:
Mr. and Mrs. Dursley, of number four, Privet Drive, were proud to say
that they were perfectly normal, thank you very much. They were the last
people you'd expect to be involved in anything strange or mysterious,
because they just didn't hold with such nonsense.
Mr. Dursley was the director of a firm called Grunnings, which made
drills. He was a big, beefy man with hardly any neck, although he did
have a very large mustache. Mrs. Dursley was thin and blonde and had
nearly twice the usual amount of neck, which came in very useful as she
spent so much of her time craning over garden fences, spying on the
neighbors. The Dursleys had a small son called Dudley and in their
opinion there was no finer boy anywhere.

0.content_hindi: श्री और श्रीमती डर्स्ली, जो नंबर चार, प्रिवेट ड्राइव में रहते थे, यह घोषणा करते हुए बहुत गर्व करते थे कि वे पूरी तरह से साधारण थे, बहुत बहुत धन्यवाद। वे ऐसे लोग थे जिनके बारे में आप कल्पना भी नहीं कर सकते थे कि वे किसी भी तरह की असामान्य या रहस्यमय चीज़ में शामिल होंगे, क्योंकि वे ऐसी अजीब या अलौकिक चीज़ों में विश्वास नहीं करते थे।

1.content:
Mr. Dursley was the director of a firm called Grunnings, which made
drills. He was a big, beefy man with hardly any neck, although he did
have a very large mustache. Mrs. Dursley was thin and blonde and had

1.content_hindi: श्री डार्सली ग्रनिंग्स नामक कंपनी के प्रमुख थे, जो ड्रिल का निर्माण करती थी। वह बहुत छोटी गर्दन वाले एक बड़े, मजबूत व्यक्ति थे, लेकिन उनकी मूछें काफी बड़ी थीं। श्रीमती डार्सली पतली और सुनहरी थीं, और उनकी गर्दन सामान्य से लगभग दोगुनी थी। यह उसके लिए बहुत काम का था क्योंकि वह बगीचे की बाड़ के पार झाँकते हुए, बगल में रहने वाले लोगों पर नज़र रखने में बहुत समय बिताती थी। डर्सलियों का एक जवान बेटा था जिसका नाम डडली था और उनके अनुसार वह आसपास का सबसे अच्छा लड़का था।

summary.page_summary_so_far: The introduction to the Dursley family, who consider themselves perfectly normal.
summary.current_page_summary: Mr. and Mrs. Dursley, proud of their ordinary lives, are described as a big, beefy man with a large mustache (Mr. Dursley) and a thin, blonde woman with an unusually long neck (Mrs. Dursley). They have a son named Dudley, whom they think is the finest boy anywhere.
summary.page_summary_so_far_hindi: कहानी डर्स्ली परिवार से परिचय कराते हुए शुरू होती है। वे सामान्य लोग हैं जो मानते हैं कि वे भी बाकी लोगों की तरह ही हैं।
summary.current_page_summary_hindi: श्री और श्रीमती डार्सली, जो अपने नियमित जीवन से बहुत खुश हैं, को एक मोटी मूछों (श्री डार्सली) के साथ एक बड़े, मजबूत व्यक्ति और एक पतली, गोरी महिला के रूप में चित्रित किया गया है, जिसकी गर्दन उल्लेखनीय रूप से लंबी है (श्रीमती डार्सली)। उनका एक बेटा है जिसका नाम डडली है, जिसे वे दुनिया का सबसे अच्छा लड़का मानते हैं।

novel_words.meaning: absurd or unreasonable behavior or ideas
novel_words.usage: The government's new policy was met with a lot of nonsense from the opposition.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: In this context, 'nonsense' refers to the Dursleys' reluctance to get involved in anything unusual or extraordinary.
novel_words.meaning_hindi: बेतुका या अनुचित व्यवहार या विचारों को अक्सर "बेतुकापन" के रूप में संदर्भित किया जाता है। इस शब्द का उपयोग उन कार्यों या विचारों का वर्णन करने के लिए किया जाता है जो अतर्कसंगत, निरर्थक या पूरी तरह से अतर्कसंगत होते हैं। उदाहरण के लिए, यदि कोई कहता है कि आसमान बैंगनी है, तो यह एक बेतुकता होगी। यह कोई तार्किक या उचित विचार नहीं है और इसका कोई मतलब नहीं है।
novel_words.usage_hindi: सरकार के इस नवीनतम निर्णय की विपक्षी पार्टी ने काफी आलोचना की थी।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: इस स्थिति में, 'बकवास' शब्द का उपयोग डर्सले की किसी भी ऐसी चीज़ में भाग लेने की अनिच्छा का वर्णन करने के लिए किया जाता है जो असाधारण या असामान्य है।

novel_words.meaning: to bend or lean forward in order to see something
novel_words.usage: She craned her neck to get a better look at the sunset.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: In this context, 'craning' refers to Mrs. Dursley's habit of leaning over garden fences to spy on her neighbors.
novel_words.meaning_hindi: कुछ देखने के लिए झुकना या आगे झुकना
novel_words.usage_hindi: उसने सूर्यास्त को और स्पष्ट रूप से देखने के लिए अपनी गर्दन आगे बढ़ाई।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: इस स्थिति में, 'क्रेनिंग' एक ऐसा शब्द है जिसका उपयोग श्रीमती डार्सली के बगीचे की बाड़ पर झुक कर अपने पड़ोसियों को गुप्त रूप से देखने के व्यवहार का वर्णन करने के लिए किया जाता है।

novel_words.meaning: absurd or unreasonable behavior or ideas
novel_words.usage: The teacher scolded the student for displaying foolishness in front of the class.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: In this context, 'foolishness' refers to the Dursleys' refusal to accept anything unusual or extraordinary.

novel_words.usage_hindi: शिक्षक ने कक्षा में सभी के सामने मूर्खतापूर्ण व्यवहार करने के लिए छात्र की आलोचना की।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: इस स्थिति में, 'मूर्खता' शब्द का उपयोग डर्सले परिवार की किसी भी असामान्य या असाधारण चीज़ को स्वीकार करने की अनिच्छा का वर्णन करने के लिए किया जाता है।

cultural_ref.significance_hindi: अभ्यास का संदर्भ औद्योगिक या विनिर्माण व्यवस्था में श्री डार्सली के काम से जुड़ा हो सकता है। यह विशेष रूप से हिंदी भाषी पाठकों के लिए महत्वपूर्ण हो सकता है जो कपड़ा या निर्माण जैसे भारतीय उद्योगों से परिचित हैं।

cultural_ref.significance: The name 'Dudley' is a common English surname that may not be immediately familiar to Hindi-speaking readers from India. The use of this name could suggest that the author is drawing on British cultural influences.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: To better understand this context, one could consider the significance of surnames in British culture and how they differ from Indian naming conventions.
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: 'डडली' उपनाम एक प्रसिद्ध अंग्रेजी नाम है जो भारत के हिंदी भाषी लोगों को शायद अच्छी तरह से ज्ञात न हो। इस तथ्य से संकेत मिल सकता है कि लेखक इस नाम का उपयोग करता है, इसका मतलब है कि वे ब्रिटिश संस्कृति के तत्वों को शामिल कर रहे हैं।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: इस स्थिति के बारे में गहरी समझ के लिए, ब्रिटिश संस्कृति में उपनामों के महत्व के बारे में सोचना सहायक हो सकता है। इसकी तुलना भारतीय संस्कृति में नामों को दिए जाने के तरीके से करना भी महत्वपूर्ण है।

cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: To better understand this context, one could consider the significance of plants and gardens in British culture and how they differ from Indian gardening practices.
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: 'प्रिवेट' शब्द एक विशिष्ट प्रकार की झाड़ी को संदर्भित करता है जिसे यू.के. में अक्सर देखा जाता है। इस संदर्भ से यह संकेत मिल सकता है कि लेखक ब्रिटिश संस्कृति से प्रेरणा ले रहा है।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: इस विषय को बेहतर ढंग से समझने के लिए, ब्रिटिश संस्कृति में पौधों और उद्यानों के महत्व के बारे में सोचना सहायक हो सकता है। इनकी तुलना भारतीयों द्वारा अपने बगीचों की देखभाल करने के तरीकों से करना भी महत्वपूर्ण है।

1.grade5: Mr. and Mrs. Dursley lived at number four, Privet Drive. They thought they were very normal and liked to say so. They didn't like anything strange or mysterious. Mr. Dursley ran a company that made drills. He was a big man with a thick mustache. Mrs. Dursley was thin and had a long neck. She liked to look over garden fences to see what her neighbors were doing. The Dursleys had a son named Dudley. They thought he was the best boy in the world.

2.content:
The Dursleys had everything they wanted, but they also had a secret, and
their greatest fear was that somebody would discover it. They didn't
think they could bear it if anyone found out about the Potters. Mrs.
Potter was Mrs. Dursley's sister, but they hadn't met for several years;
in fact, Mrs. Dursley pretended she didn't have a sister, because her
sister and her good-for-nothing husband were as unDursleyish as it was
possible to be. The Dursleys shuddered to think what the neighbors would
say if the Potters arrived in the street. The Dursleys knew that the
Potters had a small son, too, but they had never even seen him. This boy
was another good reason for keeping the Potters away; they didn't want
Dudley mixing with a child like that.

2.content_hindi: डर्सलियों के पास वह सब कुछ था जो वे कभी चाह सकते थे, लेकिन उनके पास एक रहस्य भी था कि वे डरते थे कि कोई उन्हें ढूंढ लेगा। उनका सबसे बड़ा डर यह था कि किसी को कुमारों के बारे में पता चल जाएगा। श्रीमती पॉटर श्रीमती डर्स्ली की बहन थीं, लेकिन उन्होंने वर्षों से एक-दूसरे को नहीं देखा था। वास्तव में, श्रीमती डार्सली ने नाटक किया कि उनकी कोई बहन नहीं है क्योंकि उनकी बहन और उनके पति डार्सली से यथासंभव अलग थे। डर्सले इस बात को लेकर बहुत चिंतित थे कि अगर पॉटर्स सड़क पर चले गए तो पड़ोसी क्या कहेंगे। डर्सलियों को पता था कि पॉटर्स का एक छोटा बेटा था, लेकिन उन्होंने उसे कभी देखा भी नहीं था। यह लड़का एक और कारण था कि वे पॉटर्स को दूर रखना चाहते थे; वे नहीं चाहते थे कि डडली ऐसे बच्चे के साथ मिले।

This boy was another good reason for keeping the Potters away; they didn't want Dudley mixing with a child like that.

summary.current_page_summary_hindi: डर्सलीज़ के पास वह सब कुछ था जो वे कभी चाह सकते थे, लेकिन उनके पास एक रहस्य भी था कि वे डरते थे कि कोई उन्हें ढूंढ लेगा। उनका सबसे बड़ा डर यह था कि किसी को कुमारों के बारे में पता चल जाएगा। श्रीमती पॉटर श्रीमती डार्सली की बहन थीं, लेकिन उन्होंने वर्षों से एक-दूसरे को नहीं देखा था। वास्तव में, श्रीमती डार्सली ने नाटक किया कि उनकी कोई बहन नहीं है क्योंकि उनकी बहन और उनके पति डार्सली से बहुत अलग थे। डर्सले इस बात को लेकर चिंतित थे कि अगर पॉटर उनके मोहल्ले में चले गए तो पड़ोसी क्या कहेंगे। डर्सलियों को पता था कि पॉटर्स का एक छोटा बेटा था, लेकिन वे उससे कभी नहीं मिले थे। यह लड़का एक और कारण था कि वे कुमारों को दूर रखना चाहते थे। वे नहीं चाहते थे कि उनका बेटा डडली ऐसे बच्चे के साथ मिले।

novel_words.meaning: not like or characteristic of the Dursleys
novel_words.usage: The Dursleys shuddered to think what the neighbors would say if the Potters arrived in the street, because they knew the Potters were as unDursleyish as it was possible to be.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: The word 'unDursleyish' is used to describe the Potters as being unlike or opposite to the Dursleys in terms of their values, behavior, or lifestyle.
novel_words.meaning_hindi: डर्लीज़ के समान या उनकी विशेषता नहीं
novel_words.usage_hindi: डर्सले इस बात से चिंतित थे कि अगर पॉटर उनके मोहल्ले में रहने आएँ तो पड़ोसी क्या सोचेंगे। वे जानते थे कि कुम्हार उनसे बहुत अलग थे, और वे उनसे जुड़ा नहीं रहना चाहते थे।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: 'अनडर्स्लीश' शब्द का उपयोग कुमारों को डर्स्ली के विपरीत होने के रूप में वर्णित करने के लिए किया जाता है। इसका मतलब है कि कुमारों के मूल्य, व्यवहार या जीवन शैली डार्स्ली परिवार के विपरीत है।

novel_words.meaning: useless or worthless
novel_words.usage: Mrs. Dursley pretended she didn't have a sister, because her sister and her good-for-nothing husband were as unDursleyish as it was possible to be.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: The word 'good-for-nothing' is used to describe the Potters' husband as being useless or worthless in the eyes of Mrs. Dursley.
novel_words.usage_hindi: श्रीमती डार्सली ने ऐसा अभिनय करने की कोशिश की जैसे कि उसकी कोई बहन न हो। ऐसा इसलिए था क्योंकि उसकी बहन और उसका बहनोई डार्स्ली परिवार से जितना अलग हो सकता था, उतने अलग थे।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: 'बेकार' शब्द का उपयोग कुम्हारों के पति का वर्णन करने के लिए किया जाता है, जो श्रीमती डार्सली की राय में उपयोगी या मूल्यवान नहीं है।

cultural_ref.part_of_text: Mrs. Potter was Mrs. Dursley's sister
cultural_ref.significance: This reference to 'Potter' is likely a surname, possibly of British origin, and may be relevant to the cultural context of the story. In British culture, surnames are often used to identify family relationships.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For non-native speakers from India, this reference might not be immediately clear. Providing more context about British naming conventions or explaining that 'Potter' is a surname could help improve understanding.
cultural_ref.part_of_text_hindi: श्रीमती पॉटर श्रीमती डार्सली की बहन थीं।
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: 'पॉटर' शब्द एक उपनाम हो सकता है, जो संभवतः ब्रिटेन से आया हो। कहानी की सांस्कृतिक पृष्ठभूमि को समझने के लिए यह महत्वपूर्ण हो सकता है। ब्रिटिश संस्कृति में, अंतिम नाम का उपयोग अक्सर पारिवारिक संबंध दिखाने के लिए किया जाता है।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत के उन लोगों के लिए जो मूल अंग्रेज़ी वक्ता नहीं हैं, यह संदर्भ समझना आसान नहीं होगा। ब्रिटेन में लोग अपने बच्चों का नाम कैसे रखते हैं, इसके बारे में अधिक विवरण जोड़ना या यह समझाना कि 'पॉटर' एक पारिवारिक नाम है, इसे समझना आसान बना सकता है।

cultural_ref.part_of_text: the Potters had a small son
cultural_ref.significance: This mention of the Potter family and their son may be relevant to the cultural context of the story, particularly in terms of British family dynamics. The name 'Dudley' is also mentioned, which could be important for understanding the character relationships.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For non-native speakers from India, this reference might not be familiar. Providing more context about British naming conventions or explaining that 'Dudley' is a common surname in Britain could help improve understanding.
cultural_ref.part_of_text_hindi: कुम्हारों को एक छोटा सा लड़का हुआ था
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: कहानी की सांस्कृतिक पृष्ठभूमि को समझने में कुम्हार परिवार और उनका बच्चा महत्वपूर्ण हो सकते हैं, विशेष रूप से जब ब्रिटिश पारिवारिक संरचनाओं की बात आती है। 'डडली' नाम का भी उल्लेख किया गया है, जो पात्रों के बीच के संबंधों को समझने के लिए महत्वपूर्ण हो सकता है।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत के वे लोग जो मूल अंग्रेज़ी वक्ता नहीं हैं, वे संदर्भ से परिचित नहीं होंगे। इसे स्पष्ट करने के लिए, आप इस बारे में अधिक पृष्ठभूमि जानकारी प्रदान कर सकते हैं कि ब्रिटेन में लोगों को कैसे नाम दिया जाता है। आप यह भी समझा सकते हैं कि 'डडली' ब्रिटेन में एक आम उपनाम है। इससे उन्हें संदर्भ को बेहतर ढंग से समझने में मदद मिल सकती है।

cultural_ref.part_of_text: the Dursleys shuddered to think what the neighbors would say
cultural_ref.significance: This reference to 'neighbors' and the concern about what they would say may be relevant to the cultural context of British suburban life. In some Indian cultures, social hierarchy and community expectations are important aspects of daily life.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For non-native speakers from India, this reference might not be immediately clear. Providing more context about British suburban culture or explaining that 'neighbors' refer to people living nearby could help improve understanding.
cultural_ref.part_of_text_hindi: डर्सले इस बात को लेकर चिंतित थे कि बगल में रहने वाले लोग क्या कहेंगे।
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: 'पड़ोसियों' का उल्लेख और वे क्या कह सकते हैं, इस चिंता को ब्रिटिश उपनगरीय जीवन की सांस्कृतिक व्यवस्था से जोड़ा जा सकता है। कुछ भारतीय संस्कृतियों में, सामाजिक श्रेणी और सामुदायिक अपेक्षाएं दैनिक जीवन के महत्वपूर्ण अंग हैं।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत के उन लोगों के लिए जो मूल अंग्रेज़ी वक्ता नहीं हैं, यह संदर्भ समझना आसान नहीं होगा। ब्रिटिश उपनगरीय संस्कृति के बारे में अधिक विवरण जोड़ना या यह समझाना कि 'पड़ोसी' वे लोग हैं जो पास में रहते हैं, इसे समझना आसान बना सकता है।

2.grade5: The Dursleys had everything they wanted, but they also had a secret. They were afraid someone would discover it. They worried that if anyone found out about the Potters, they wouldn't be able to handle it. Mrs. Potter was Mrs. Dursley's sister, but they hadn't seen each other in years. Mrs. Dursley didn't want people to know she had a sister who was very different from her. The Dursleys were afraid of what the neighbors would say if the Potters moved in next door. They knew that the Potters had a little boy, but they had never even seen him. This boy made it even more important for them to keep the Potters away. They didn't want Dudley to play with someone who was so different from him.

3.content:
When Mr. and Mrs. Dursley woke up on the dull, gray Tuesday our story
starts, there was nothing about the cloudy sky outside to suggest that
strange and mysterious things would soon be happening all over the
country. Mr. Dursley hummed as he picked out his most boring tie for
work, and Mrs. Dursley gossiped away happily as she wrestled a screaming
Dudley into his high chair.
None of them noticed a large, tawny owl flutter past the window.
At half past eight, Mr. Dursley picked up his briefcase, pecked Mrs.
Dursley on the cheek, and tried to kiss Dudley good-bye but missed,
because Dudley was now having a tantrum and throwing his cereal at the
walls. "Little tyke," chortled Mr. Dursley as he left the house. He got
into his car and backed out of number four's drive.

3.content_hindi: जब श्री और श्रीमती डार्सली एक सुस्त, धूसर मंगलवार को जागे, तो बादलों से भरे आसमान में कुछ भी नहीं था जो उन असामान्य और दिलचस्प घटनाओं का संकेत दे रहा था जो जल्द ही देश भर में सामने आने वाली थीं। श्रीमान डार्सली ने काम पर जाने के लिए अपनी सबसे बेमन टाई चुनते हुए सीटी बजाई और श्रीमती डार्सली ने रोते-बिलखते डडल को अपनी ऊंची कुर्सी में शांत करने के लिए संघर्ष करते हुए खुशी-खुशी बात की।

4.content: None of them noticed a large, tawny owl flutter past the window.
4.content_hindi: किसी ने एक बड़े, सुनहरे-भूरे उल्लू को खिड़की के पास उड़ते हुए नहीं देखा।

5.content:

Dursley on the cheek, and tried to kiss Dudley good-bye but missed,
because Dudley was now having a tantrum and throwing his cereal at the
walls. "Little tyke," chortled Mr. Dursley as he left the house. He got
into his car and backed out of number four's drive.
5.content_hindi: 8:30 पर, श्री. डार्सली ने अपना ब्रीफकेस उठाया, श्रीमती डार्सली के गाल पर एक त्वरित चूमा, और डडली को अलविदा कहने के लिए एक चुंबन देने का प्रयास किया। हालाँकि, डडली गुस्से में था, और अपने अनाज को दीवारों पर फेंक रहा था। श्रीमान डार्सली डडली के व्यवहार पर हंसते हुए घर से बाहर निकलने के लिए मजबूर हो गए। इसके बाद वह अपनी कार में बैठ गया और उनके घर की ड्राइववे से बाहर निकला, जो नंबर चार पर था।

summary.page_summary_so_far: Mr. and Mrs. Dursley, proud of their ordinary lives, are described as a big, beefy man with a large mustache (Mr. Dursley) and a thin, blonde woman with an unusually long neck (Mrs. Dursley). They have a son named Dudley, whom they think is the finest boy anywhere.
summary.current_page_summary: The story begins on a dull, gray Tuesday morning when Mr. and Mrs. Dursley wake up. Despite the gloomy weather outside, their ordinary routine continues with Mr. Dursley picking out his tie, Mrs. Dursley gossiping with her son Dudley, and none of them noticing a large owl fluttering past the window. As they prepare to leave for work and school, the family's mundane morning is filled with chaos as Dudley throws a tantrum, making it difficult for Mr. Dursley to kiss him goodbye.
summary.page_summary_so_far_hindi: श्री और श्रीमती डार्सली, जो अपने नियमित जीवन से बहुत खुश हैं, को एक मोटी मूछों (श्री डार्सली) के साथ एक बड़े, मजबूत व्यक्ति और एक पतली, गोरी महिला के रूप में चित्रित किया गया है, जिसकी गर्दन उल्लेखनीय रूप से लंबी है (श्रीमती डार्सली)। उनका एक बेटा है जिसका नाम डडली है, जिसे वे दुनिया का सबसे अच्छा लड़का मानते हैं।
summary.current_page_summary_hindi: कहानी एक सुस्त, धूसर मंगलवार की सुबह से शुरू होती है। श्री और श्रीमती डार्सली जाग जाते हैं। बाहर के खराब मौसम के बावजूद, वे अपना सामान्य दिनचर्या जारी रखते हैं। श्री डार्सली अपनी टाई चुनते हैं, श्रीमती डार्सली अपने बेटे डडली के साथ बातें करती हैं, और उनमें से कोई भी खिड़की के पार उड़ते हुए एक बड़े उल्लू पर ध्यान नहीं देता है। जैसे ही वे काम और स्कूल जाने के लिए तैयार होते हैं, सुबह अराजक हो जाती है। डडली गुस्सा हो जाता है, जिससे श्री. डार्सली के लिए उसे अलविदा कहना मुश्किल हो जाता है।

novel_words.meaning: having a brownish-yellow color
novel_words.usage: The tawny owl perched on the branch, its feathers blending with the surroundings.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: In this context, 'tawny' is used to describe the owl's color, which helps it blend in with its environment.
novel_words.usage_hindi: केसरिया उल्लू एक शाखा पर बैठा था, उसके पंख उसके वातावरण के रंगों से मेल खाते थे।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: इस स्थिति में उल्लू के रंग का वर्णन करने के लिए 'तपकिरी' शब्द का उपयोग किया जाता है। यह रंग उल्लू को अपने परिवेश के साथ मिश्रित होने में मदद करता है, जिससे यह कम ध्यान देने योग्य हो जाता है।

novel_words.meaning: to talk excessively and often about other people's business
novel_words.usage: The neighbors gossiped about each other's personal lives, making the atmosphere uncomfortable.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: In this context, 'gossiped' is used to describe Mrs. Dursley's behavior of talking happily and excessively about her family.
novel_words.meaning_hindi: अधिक मात्रा में और अक्सर दूसरे लोगों के व्यवसाय के बारे में बात करना
novel_words.usage_hindi: पड़ोसी एक-दूसरे के निजी मामलों के बारे में बात करते थे, जिससे स्थिति तनावपूर्ण और अजीब हो जाती थी।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: इस स्थिति में, श्रीमती डार्सली के खुश होकर बातें करने और अपने परिवार के बारे में बहुत कुछ कहने के व्यवहार का वर्णन करने के लिए 'गॉसिप' शब्द का उपयोग किया जाता है।

novel_words.meaning: to laugh loudly and heartily
novel_words.usage: The comedian chortled as he told the joke, making the audience laugh.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: In this context, 'chortled' is used to describe Mr. Dursley's reaction to Dudley's tantrum.
novel_words.meaning_hindi: जोर से और दिल से हँसना
novel_words.usage_hindi: जब हास्य कलाकार ने मजाक साझा किया तो वह जोर से हँसे, जिससे भीड़ हँसने लगी।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: इस स्थिति में, डडली के गुस्से के उद्गार पर श्री. डार्सली की प्रतिक्रिया का वर्णन करने के लिए 'हंसने' शब्द का उपयोग किया जाता है।

novel_words.meaning: a young boy or a pet dog
novel_words.usage: The little tyke ran around the park, playing with his friends.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: In this context, 'tyke' is used to affectionately refer to Dudley as a young boy.
novel_words.meaning_hindi: एक छोटा लड़का या पालतू कुत्ता
novel_words.usage_hindi: छोटा बच्चा अपने दोस्तों के साथ उद्यान में इधर-उधर भाग रहा था, मस्ती कर रहा था।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: इस स्थिति में, 'टाइक' शब्द का उपयोग डडली के बचपन को संदर्भित करने के लिए प्यार से किया जाता है।

cultural_ref.significance: The reference to 'number four's drive' is likely a nod to the British culture of numbering houses and buildings. In the UK, it was common for houses to be numbered in sequence, with each house having a unique number. This practice has its roots in medieval England, where houses were often identified by their location within a village or town.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: This detail helps non-native speakers understand that the story is set in the UK and provides insight into British culture and history.
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: 'चौथी संख्या के ड्राइव' का उल्लेख घरों और इमारतों को संख्या सौंपने की ब्रिटिश परंपरा का संकेत हो सकता है। यू.के. में, घरों को आम तौर पर एक विशिष्ट क्रम में संख्या दी जाती थी, प्रत्येक का एक अलग नंबर होता था। यह परंपरा मध्ययुगीन इंग्लैंड में शुरू हुई, जहाँ अक्सर घरों की पहचान गाँव या शहर के भीतर उनकी स्थिति से की जाती थी।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: यह जानकारी उन लोगों को समझने में मदद करती है जो मूल अंग्रेजी वक्ता नहीं हैं कि कहानी यूनाइटेड किंगडम में घटित होती है। यह उन्हें ब्रिटिश संस्कृति और इतिहास की भी एक झलक देता है।

cultural_ref.significance: The name 'Dudley' has English origins, specifically from the Old English word 'dūdlēah', meaning 'valley'. It's also possible that the author chose this name to evoke a sense of ordinariness and normalcy, which contrasts with the extraordinary events that unfold later in the story.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: This detail helps non-native speakers understand the cultural context of the story and appreciate the subtlety of J.K. Rowling's character naming choices.
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: 'डडली' नाम अंग्रेजी मूल से आया है। यह पुरानी अंग्रेजी शब्द 'डूडलेह' से लिया गया है, जिसका अनुवाद 'घाटी' होता है। लेखक ने शायद यह नाम एक नियमित या औसत चरित्र का सुझाव देने के लिए चुना होगा, जो कहानी में बाद में होने वाली असामान्य घटनाओं को देखते हुए दिलचस्प होगा।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: यह जानकारी उन लोगों को कहानी की सांस्कृतिक पृष्ठभूमि को समझने और जे.के. रॉलिंग के चरित्र के नाम चयन की चतुरता की सराहना करने में मदद करती है जो मूल अंग्रेजी वक्ता नहीं हैं।

3.grade5: One morning, when Mr. and Mrs. Dursley woke up on a gray Tuesday, our story began. The cloudy sky outside didn't seem like anything special. Mr. Dursley got dressed in his usual boring clothes for work, and Mrs. Dursley chatted happily with her son, Dudley, as she tried to calm him down. None of them noticed a big owl flying by the window. At 8:30, Mr. Dursley packed up his bag, kissed his wife on the cheek, and said goodbye to his son, but missed because Dudley was having a tantrum and throwing cereal everywhere. 'Little troublemaker,' Mr. Dursley joked as he left the house in his car.

4.content:
It was on the corner of the street that he noticed the first sign of
something peculiar -- a cat reading a map. For a second, Mr. Dursley
didn't realize what he had seen -- then he jerked his head around to
look again. There was a tabby cat standing on the corner of Privet
Drive, but there wasn't a map in sight. What could he have been thinking
of? It must have been a trick of the light. Mr. Dursley blinked and
stared at the cat. It stared back. As Mr. Dursley drove around the
corner and up the road, he watched the cat in his mirror. It was now
reading the sign that said Privet Drive -- no, looking at the sign; cats
couldn't read maps or signs. Mr. Dursley gave himself a little shake and
put the cat out of his mind. As he drove toward town he thought of
nothing except a large order of drills he was hoping to get that day.

6.content_hindi: श्रीमान डार्सली सड़क पर चल रहे थे जब उन्होंने कुछ अजीब देखा। एक बिल्ली मानचित्र पढ़ रही थी। पहले तो उसे यकीन नहीं हुआ कि वह क्या देख रहा है, लेकिन फिर उसने फिर से देखा। बिल्ली एक टैबी थी और प्रिवेट ड्राइव के कोने पर खड़ी थी। लेकिन नक्शा कहीं नज़र नहीं आ रहा था। श्री डार्सली ने सोचा कि यह शायद प्रकाश की एक चाल थी। उसने पलक झपकी और फिर से बिल्ली को देखा। बिल्ली ने उसे पीछे मुड़कर देखा। जैसे ही मिस्टर डार्सली ने मोड़ पर और सड़क के ऊपर गाड़ी चलाई, उन्होंने अपने पीछे के दर्पण में बिल्ली पर नज़र रखी। बिल्ली अब उस संकेत को देख रही थी जिस पर लिखा था 'प्रिवेट ड्राइव'। श्री डार्सली को पता था कि बिल्लियाँ मानचित्र या संकेत नहीं पढ़ सकती हैं, इसलिए उन्होंने अपना सिर हिलाया और बिल्ली के बारे में भूल गए। जैसे ही वह शहर की ओर बढ़े, उन्होंने एक बड़े अभ्यास के आदेश के बारे में सोचा जो उन्हें उस दिन मिलने की उम्मीद थी।

summary.page_summary_so_far: Mr. and Mrs. Dursley, proud of their ordinary lives, are described as a big, beefy man with a large mustache (Mr. Dursley) and a thin, blonde woman with an unusually long neck (Mrs. Dursley). They have a son named Dudley, whom they think is the finest boy anywhere.
summary.current_page_summary: Mr. Dursley notices a peculiar sight on the corner of Privet Drive - a cat reading a map. He initially thinks he's seeing things, but when he looks again, the cat is indeed staring back at him, seemingly reading the sign that says 'Privet Drive'. Mr. Dursley tries to shake off the strange occurrence and focuses on his upcoming drill order.
summary.page_summary_so_far_hindi: श्री और श्रीमती डार्सली, जो अपने साधारण अस्तित्व से बहुत खुश हैं, को एक मोटी मूछों (श्री डार्सली) के साथ एक बड़े, मजबूत व्यक्ति और एक असामान्य रूप से लंबी गर्दन (श्रीमती डार्सली) के साथ एक पतली, गोरी महिला के रूप में चित्रित किया गया है। उनका एक बेटा है जिसका नाम डडली है, जिसे वे दुनिया का सबसे अच्छा लड़का मानते हैं।
summary.current_page_summary_hindi: श्री डार्सली को प्रिवेट ड्राइव के कोने पर कुछ असामान्य दिखाई देता है - एक बिल्ली जो मानचित्र को देख रही है। पहले तो वह सोचता है कि क्या वह सिर्फ चीज़ों की कल्पना कर रहा है, लेकिन जब वह फिर से देखता है, तो बिल्ली निश्चित रूप से उसे वापस देख रही है, जैसे कि वह 'प्रिवेट ड्राइव' कहने वाले संकेत का अध्ययन कर रही है। श्री डार्सली इस अजीब घटना को नजरअंदाज करने की कोशिश करते हैं और इसके बजाय अपने आगामी अभ्यास आदेश पर ध्यान केंद्रित करते हैं।

novel_words.meaning: a type of domestic cat with a brown or reddish-brown coat and white markings
novel_words.usage: The tabby cat stood on the corner of Privet Drive, its fur fluffed up in agitation.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: In this context, 'tabby' is used to describe a specific type of domestic cat that Mr. Dursley sees

novel_words.usage_hindi: टैबी बिल्ली प्राइवेट ड्राइव के चौराहे पर स्थित थी, उसका लोमच उछला हुआ था और वह परेशान लग रही थी।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: इस स्थिति में, 'टैबी' शब्द का उपयोग घरेलू बिल्ली की एक निश्चित नस्ल का वर्णन करने के लिए किया जाता है जिसे श्री. डार्सली देखते हैं।

novel_words.meaning: long, thin tools used for making holes or driving screws
novel_words.usage: Mr. Dursley was hoping to get a large order of drills that day, which would help him with his woodworking project.
novel_words.meaning_in_context: In this context, 'drills' refers to the tools Mr. Dursley is interested in purchasing
novel_words.meaning_hindi: लंबे, पतले उपकरणों का उपयोग अक्सर दो मुख्य उद्देश्यों के लिए किया जाता हैः छेद बनाना या पेंच चलाना।
novel_words.usage_hindi: श्री डर्सली उस दिन अभ्यास के लिए एक बड़ा ऑर्डर देने के लिए उत्सुक थे। ऐसा इसलिए था क्योंकि वह एक लकड़ी के काम की परियोजना पर काम कर रहा था और इसे पूरा करने के लिए उसे बहुत सारे अभ्यासों की आवश्यकता थी।
novel_words.meaning_in_context_hindi: इस स्थिति में, 'अभ्यास' से तात्पर्य है उन उपकरणों को जो श्री. डार्सली खरीदना चाहते हैं।

cultural_ref.significance: Privet Drive is likely a fictional address, but it may be inspired by real-life streets in England or other parts of the UK. The name 'Privet' could also refer to a type of shrub commonly found in English gardens.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For Hindi-speaking readers from India, understanding the context of Privet Drive can help them visualize the setting of the story as being in England or another Western country.
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: प्रिवेट ड्राइव शायद एक बनाया-बुलाया पता है, लेकिन यह इंग्लैंड या यू.के. के अन्य हिस्सों की वास्तविक सड़कों पर आधारित हो सकता है। 'प्रिवेट' शब्द अंग्रेजी बगीचों में अक्सर पाए जाने वाले एक सामान्य प्रकार के झाऊँड का भी संदर्भ हो सकता है।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: जो लोग हिंदी बोलते हैं और भारत से हैं, उन्हें अगर प्रिवेट ड्राइव के बारे में पता हो तो उन्हें कहानी के परिवेश की कल्पना करना आसान हो सकता है। यह ज्ञान उन्हें इंग्लैंड या किसी अन्य पश्चिमी देश में होने वाली कहानी की कल्पना करने में मदद कर सकता है।

cultural_ref.significance: Tabby cats are a common breed found in many parts of the world, including India. However, the context of the story suggests that this cat is behaving in an unusual manner, which may be intended to grab the reader's attention.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For Hindi-speaking readers from India, recognizing the type of cat mentioned can help them better understand the character and setting of the story.
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: टैबी बिल्लियाँ एक प्रसिद्ध नस्ल हैं जो भारत सहित कई स्थानों पर पाई जा सकती हैं। लेकिन कहानी में, यह बिल्ली इस तरह से व्यवहार कर रही है जो उसकी नस्ल के लिए विशिष्ट नहीं है। इस असामान्य व्यवहार का उपयोग पाठकों को अधिक ध्यान देने के लिए किया जा सकता है।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत में हिंदी बोलने वाले लोगों के लिए, जिस बिल्ली के बारे में बात की जा रही है, उसे जानना कहानी के चरित्र और वातावरण को समझना आसान बना सकता है।

cultural_ref.significance: Drills are a common tool used in various industries, including construction. The fact that Mr. Dursley is hoping to get an order of drills suggests that he may be involved in some kind of work or business.
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: For Hindi-speaking readers from India, understanding the context of drills can help them better visualize Mr. Dursley's occupation and interests.
cultural_ref.significance_hindi: ड्रिल निर्माण सहित कई क्षेत्रों में अक्सर उपयोग किया जाने वाला उपकरण है। यह तथ्य कि श्री डार्सली अभ्यास के आदेश की प्रतीक्षा कर रहे हैं, इसका तात्पर्य है कि वे किसी प्रकार के काम या व्यवसाय में व्यस्त हो सकते हैं।
cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text_hindi: भारत में हिंदी बोलने वाले लोगों के लिए, अभ्यासों के अर्थ को समझना आसान हो सकता है यदि वे कल्पना कर सकते हैं कि श्री. डार्सली आजीविका के लिए क्या करते हैं और वह क्या करना पसंद करते हैं।

4.grade5: One day, Mr. Dursley saw something strange on the corner of the street. A cat was standing there, looking at a map. For a moment, Mr. Dursley didn't believe what he saw - then he looked again. There was a tabby cat on the corner of Privet Drive, but it wasn't holding a map. What could he have been thinking? Maybe it was just a trick of the light. Mr. Dursley blinked and stared at the cat. The cat stared back at him. As Mr. Dursley drove around the corner and up the road, he watched the cat in his mirror. Now, the cat was looking at the sign that said Privet Drive - not reading a map! Mr. Dursley shook his head and tried to forget about the strange cat. He thought about an important order of drills he needed to get that day.

5.content:
But on the edge of town, drills were driven out of his mind by something
else. As he sat in the usual morning traffic jam, he couldn't help
noticing that there seemed to be a lot of strangely dressed people
about. People in cloaks. Mr. Dursley couldn't bear people who dressed in
funny clothes -- the getups you saw on young people! He supposed this
was some stupid new fashion. He drummed his fingers on the steering
wheel and his eyes fell on a huddle of these weirdos standing quite
close by. They were whispering excitedly together. Mr. Dursley was
enraged to see that a couple of them weren't young at all; why, that man
had to be older than he was, and wearing an emerald-green cloak! The
nerve of him! But then it struck Mr. Dursley that this was probably some
silly stunt -- these people were obviously collecting for something...
yes, that would be it. The traffic moved on and a few minutes later, Mr.
Dursley arrived in the Grunnings parking lot, his mind back on drills.

yes, that would be it. The traffic moved on and a few minutes later, Mr.

7.content_hindi: चूंकि श्री. डार्सली शहर के बाहरी इलाके में यातायात में फंस गए थे, इसलिए अभ्यास के बारे में उनके विचार किसी और चीज़ से बाधित हो गए। उन्होंने देखा कि बहुत से लोग असामान्य कपड़े पहने हुए हैं। वे लबादियों में सजे हुए थे, जो वास्तव में श्री. डार्सली को परेशान करते थे। उन्हें अजीब कपड़े पहनने वाले लोग पसंद नहीं थे, विशेष रूप से वे जो उन्होंने युवाओं में देखे। उन्होंने सोचा कि यह एक नया फैशन रुझान होगा, लेकिन उन्हें यह पसंद नहीं आया। उसने अपनी उंगलियों को स्टीयरिंग व्हील पर रखा और उसकी नज़रें पास में खड़े अजीब कपड़े पहने लोगों के एक समूह पर पड़ीं। वे आपस में चुपचाप बात कर रहे थे। श्री डार्सली यह देखकर परेशान हो गए कि उनमें से कुछ जवान नहीं थे; वास्तव में, वह आदमी उनसे बड़ा लग रहा था, और उसने एक चमकीले हरे रंग का लबादा पहना हुआ था! श्री डार्सली इससे नाराज़ हो गए। लेकिन फिर उसे एहसास हुआ कि यह शायद कोई मूर्खतापूर्ण स्टंट हो सकता है। ये लोग शायद किसी चीज़ के लिए इकट्ठा हो रहे थे। हाँ, यह तो होना ही चाहिए। कुछ मिनट बाद, श्री. डार्सली ग्रनिंग्स पार्किंग स्थल पर आ गए और उनका दिमाग फिर से अभ्यास पर केंद्रित हो गया।

summary.page_summary_so_far: Mr. and Mrs. Dursley, proud of their ordinary lives, are described as a big, beefy man with a large mustache (Mr. Dursley) and a thin, blonde woman with an unusually long neck (Mrs. Dursley). They have a son named Dudley, whom they think is the finest boy anywhere.
summary.current_page_summary: As Mr. Dursley commutes to work, he notices a group of people dressed in cloaks, which angers him due to their unconventional fashion sense. However, upon closer inspection, he realizes that some of these individuals may not be young and are likely collecting for charity or a cause.
summary.page_summary_so_far_hindi: श्री और श्रीमती डार्सली, जो अपने नियमित जीवन से बहुत खुश हैं, उन्हें एक मोटी मूछों (श्री डार्सली) के साथ एक बड़े, मजबूत व्यक्ति और एक पतली, गोरी महिला के रूप में चित्रित किया गया है, जिसकी गर्दन उल्लेखनीय रूप से लंबी है (श्रीमती डार्सली)। उनका एक बेटा है जिसका नाम डडली है, जिसके बारे में उनका मानना है कि वह दुनिया का सबसे अच्छा लड़का है।
summary.current_page_summary_hindi: श्रीमान डार्सली काम पर जाते समय लबादियों पहने लोगों के एक समूह को देखते हैं। यह दृश्य उसे परेशान कर देता है क्योंकि वह उनके असामान्य कपड़ों को पसंद नहीं करता है। लेकिन जैसे ही वह करीब से देखता है, उसे लगता है कि ये लोग शायद युवा नहीं हैं। उसे आश्चर्य होने लगता है कि क्या वे किसी अच्छे उद्देश्य या धर्मार्थ के लिए पैसे एकत्र कर रहे हैं।

5.grade5: One day, while driving to school, Mr. Dursley noticed something strange. There were many people wearing unusual clothes in the traffic jam. He didn't like people who wore funny clothes - it made him uncomfortable. He thought maybe this was a new fashion trend that he didn't understand. As he looked around, he saw some older people talking excitedly with younger people. One of them was wearing an emerald-green cloak! Mr. Dursley got annoyed because the man was much older than him and wore such an unusual outfit. But then he thought maybe this was just a silly prank - these people were probably collecting money for something...

6.content:
Mr. Dursley always sat with his back to the window in his office on the
ninth floor. If he hadn't, he might have found it harder to concentrate
on drills that morning. He didn't see the owls swoop ing past in broad
daylight, though people down in the street did; they pointed and gazed
open- mouthed as owl after owl sped overhead. Most of them had never
seen an owl even at nighttime. Mr. Dursley, however, had a perfectly
normal, owl-free morning. He yelled at five different people. He made
several important telephone calls and shouted a bit more. He was in a
very good mood until lunchtime, when he thought he'd stretch his legs
and walk across the road to buy himself a bun from the bakery.
He'd forgotten all about the people in cloaks until he passed a group of
them next to the baker's. He eyed them angrily as he passed. He didn't
know why, but they made him uneasy. This bunch were whispering
excitedly, too, and he couldn't see a single collecting tin. It was on
his way back past them, clutching a large doughnut in a bag, that he
caught a few words of what they were saying.

cultural_ref.significance: The mention of owls flying during broad daylight is a reference to European folklore, where owls are often associated with witchcraft and magic. This context might be unfamiliar to Hindi-speaking people from India, who may not have a similar cultural association with owls.

cultural_ref.improve_understanding_of_text: This detail helps to establish the fantastical elements of the story and sets the tone for the magical world that Harry Potter will inhabit.

6.grade5: Mr. Dursley sat with his back to the window in his office on the ninth floor. If he hadn't, he might have had trouble focusing on his work that morning. He didn't see any owls flying by in broad daylight, but people outside saw them and were amazed. Most of them had never seen an owl before, even at night. Mr. Dursley had a normal day without seeing any owls. He yelled at five different people, made important phone calls, and shouted some more. He was happy until lunchtime, when he decided to walk across the road to buy a bun from the bakery. On his way back, he saw a group of people in cloaks next to the baker's shop. They were whispering excitedly and didn't have any collecting tins. It made Mr. Dursley feel uneasy. He didn't know why, but they bothered him. When he passed them again, clutching a doughnut in a bag, he heard some of what they were saying.

7.content:
"The Potters, that's right, that's what I heard yes, their son, Harry"
Mr. Dursley stopped dead. Fear flooded him. He looked back at the
whisperers as if he wanted to say something to them, but thought better
of it.
He dashed back across the road, hurried up to his office, snapped at his
secretary not to disturb him, seized his telephone, and had almost
finished dialing his home number when he changed his mind. He put the
receiver back down and stroked his mustache, thinking... no, he was
being stupid. Potter wasn't such an unusual name. He was sure there were
lots of people called Potter who had a son called Harry. Come to think
of it, he wasn't even sure his nephew was called Harry. He'd never even
seen the boy. It might have been Harvey. Or Harold. There was no point
in worrying Mrs. Dursley; she always got so upset at any mention of her
sister. He didn't blame her -- if he'd had a sister like that... but all
the same, those people in cloaks...

7.grade5: Mr. Dursley stopped dead with fear. He looked back at the people whispering to him and wanted to say something, but didn't. He quickly ran across the road, went into his office, told his secretary not to bother him, picked up the phone, and was about to call his home number when he changed his mind. He put the receiver down and thought for a moment. Maybe Harry Potter wasn't such an unusual name after all. It's possible that lots of people have a son named Harry. In fact, he wasn't even sure if his nephew was called Harry. He had never seen the boy before. Maybe it was Harvey or Harold instead. There was no point in worrying about Mrs. Dursley; she gets upset whenever someone mentions her sister. Mr. Dursley didn't blame her - if he had a sister like that, he would be worried too! But still, those people in black robes were mysterious and scary.

8.content:
He found it a lot harder to concentrate on drills that afternoon and
when he left the building at five o'clock, he was still so worried that
he walked straight into someone just outside the door.
"Sorry," he grunted, as the tiny old man stumbled and almost fell. It
was a few seconds before Mr. Dursley realized that the man was wearing a
violet cloak. He didn't seem at all upset at being almost knocked to the
ground. On the contrary, his face split into a wide smile and he said in
a squeaky voice that made passersby stare, "Don't be sorry, my dear sir,
for nothing could upset me today! Rejoice, for You-Know-Who has gone at
last! Even Muggles like yourself should be celebrating, this happy,
happy day!"
And the old man hugged Mr. Dursley around the middle and walked off.
Mr. Dursley stood rooted to the spot. He had been hugged by a complete
stranger. He also thought he had been called a Muggle, whatever that
was. He was rattled. He hurried to his car and set off for home, hoping
he was imagining things, which he had never hoped before, because he
didn't approve of imagination.

9.content:
As he pulled into the driveway of number four, the first thing he saw --
and it didn't improve his mood -- was the tabby cat he'd spotted that
morning. It was now sitting on his garden wall. He was sure it was the
same one; it had the same markings around its eyes.
"Shoo!" said Mr. Dursley loudly. The cat didn't move. It just gave him a
stern look. Was this normal cat behavior? Mr. Dursley wondered. Trying
to pull himself together, he let himself into the house. He was still
determined not to mention anything to his wife.
Mrs. Dursley had had a nice, normal day. She told him over dinner all
about Mrs. Next Door's problems with her daughter and how Dudley had
learned a new word ("Won't!"). Mr. Dursley tried to act normally. When
Dudley had been put to bed, he went into the living room in time to
catch the last report on the evening news:

9.grade5: When he pulled into his driveway at number four, Mr. Dursley saw something that made him feel worse. The tabby cat he had seen earlier was sitting on his garden wall. It looked exactly like the one he had seen that morning. 'Shoo!' Mr. Dursley shouted loudly. But the cat didn't move. Instead, it gave him a stern look. Was this normal for a cat? Mr. Dursley wondered. He tried to calm down and went inside the house. He wasn't going to tell his wife about the strange cat. Mrs. Dursley had had a nice day. She told her husband all about Mrs. Next Door's problems with her daughter and how their son Dudley learned a new word ('Won't!'). Mr. Dursley tried to act normal. When Dudley went to bed, he went into the living room just in time to hear the last part of the evening news report.

10.content:
"And finally, bird-watchers everywhere have reported that the nation's
owls have been behaving very unusually today. Although owls normally
hunt at night and are hardly ever seen in daylight, there have been
hundreds of sightings of these birds flying in every direction since
sunrise. Experts are unable to explain why the owls have suddenly
changed their sleeping pattern." The newscaster allowed himself a grin.
"Most mysterious. And now, over to Jim McGuffin with the weather. Going
to be any more showers of owls tonight, Jim?"
"Well, Ted," said the weatherman, "I don't know about that, but it's not
only the owls that have been acting oddly today. Viewers as far apart as
Kent, Yorkshire, and Dundee have been phoning in to tell me that instead
of the rain I promised yesterday, they've had a downpour of shooting
stars! Perhaps people have been celebrating Bonfire Night early -- it's
not until next week, folks! But I can promise a wet night tonight."

11.content:
Mr. Dursley sat frozen in his armchair. Shooting stars all over Britain?
Owls flying by daylight? Mysterious people in cloaks all over the place?
And a whisper, a whisper about the Potters...
Mrs. Dursley came into the living room carrying two cups of tea. It was
no good. He'd have to say something to her. He cleared his throat
nervously. "Er -- Petunia, dear -- you haven't heard from your sister
lately, have you?"
As he had expected, Mrs. Dursley looked shocked and angry. After all,
they normally pretended she didn't have a sister.
"No," she said sharply. "Why?"
"Funny stuff on the news," Mr. Dursley mumbled. "Owls... shooting
stars... and there were a lot of funny-looking people in town today..."
"So?" snapped Mrs. Dursley.
"Well, I just thought... maybe... it was something to do with... you
know... her crowd."
Mrs. Dursley sipped her tea through pursed lips. Mr. Dursley wondered
whether he dared tell her he'd heard the name "Potter." He decided he
didn't dare. Instead he said, as casually as he could, "Their son --
he'd be about Dudley's age now, wouldn't he?"
"I suppose so," said Mrs. Dursley stiffly.

12.content:
"What's his name again? Howard, isn't it?"
"Harry. Nasty, common name, if you ask me."
"Oh, yes," said Mr. Dursley, his heart sinking horribly. "Yes, I quite
agree."
He didn't say another word on the subject as they went upstairs to bed.
While Mrs. Dursley was in the bathroom, Mr. Dursley crept to the bedroom
window and peered down into the front garden. The cat was still there.
It was staring down Privet Drive as though it were waiting for
something.
Was he imagining things? Could all this have anything to do with the
Potters? If it did... if it got out that they were related to a pair of
-- well, he didn't think he could bear it.

13.content:
The Dursleys got into bed. Mrs. Dursley fell asleep quickly but Mr.
Dursley lay awake, turning it all over in his mind. His last, comforting
thought before he fell asleep was that even if the Potters were
involved, there was no reason for them to come near him and Mrs.
Dursley. The Potters knew very well what he and Petunia thought about
them and their kind.... He couldn't see how he and Petunia could get
mixed up in anything that might be going on -- he yawned and turned over
-- it couldn't affect them....
How very wrong he was.
Mr. Dursley might have been drifting into an uneasy sleep, but the cat
on the wall outside was showing no sign of sleepiness. It was sitting as
still as a statue, its eyes fixed unblinkingly on the far corner of
Privet Drive. It didn't so much as quiver when a car door slammed on the
next street, nor when two owls swooped overhead. In fact, it was nearly
midnight before the cat moved at all.
A man appeared on the corner the cat had been watching, appeared so
suddenly and silently you'd have thought he'd just popped out of the
ground. The cat's tail twitched and its eyes narrowed.

36.content:
The Dursleys got into bed. Mrs. Dursley fell asleep quickly but Mr.
Dursley lay awake, turning it all over in his mind. His last, comforting
thought before he fell asleep was that even if the Potters were
involved, there was no reason for them to come near him and Mrs.
Dursley. The Potters knew very well what he and Petunia thought about
them and their kind.... He couldn't see how he and Petunia could get
mixed up in anything that might be going on -- he yawned and turned over
-- it couldn't affect them....

13.grade5: The Dursleys went to bed. Mrs. Dursley fell asleep fast, but Mr. Dursley couldn't sleep. He was thinking about everything. His last thought before he fell asleep was that the Potters wouldn't come near him and his wife, Petunia. The Potters knew what he and Petunia didn't like about them. Mr. Dursley thought it was impossible for him and Petunia to get involved in anything that might happen. He yawned and turned over - it couldn't affect them, he thought. But he was wrong.

14.content:
Nothing like this man had ever been seen on Privet Drive. He was tall,
thin, and very old, judging by the silver of his hair and beard, which
were both long enough to tuck into his belt. He was wearing long robes,
a purple cloak that swept the ground, and high-heeled, buckled boots.
His blue eyes were light, bright, and sparkling behind half-moon
spectacles and his nose was very long and crooked, as though it had been
broken at least twice. This man's name was Albus Dumbledore.
Albus Dumbledore didn't seem to realize that he had just arrived in a
street where everything from his name to his boots was unwelcome. He was
busy rummaging in his cloak, looking for something. But he did seem to
realize he was being watched, because he looked up suddenly at the cat,
which was still staring at him from the other end of the street. For
some reason, the sight of the cat seemed to amuse him. He chuckled and
muttered, "I should have known."

14.grade5: There was no one like this man on Privet Drive. He was very tall and thin, with long silver hair and beard that reached down to his belt. He wore long robes, a purple cloak that touched the ground, and high-heeled boots with buckles. His blue eyes sparkled behind half-moon glasses, and his nose was crooked like it had been broken before. This man's name was Albus Dumbledore. Dumbledore didn't notice that he looked out of place on the street because everything about him seemed strange. He was searching for something in his cloak, but then he saw the cat watching him from across the street. The sight of the cat made him laugh and say, 'I should have known.'

15.content:
He found what he was looking for in his inside pocket. It seemed to be a
silver cigarette lighter. He flicked it open, held it up in the air, and
clicked it. The nearest street lamp went out with a little pop. He
clicked it again -- the next lamp flickered into darkness. Twelve times
he clicked the Put-Outer, until the only lights left on the whole street
were two tiny pinpricks in the distance, which were the eyes of the cat
watching him. If anyone looked out of their window now, even beady-eyed
Mrs. Dursley, they wouldn't be able to see anything that was happening
down on the pavement. Dumbledore slipped the Put-Outer back inside his
cloak and set off down the street toward number four, where he sat down
on the wall next to the cat. He didn't look at it, but after a moment he
spoke to it.
"Fancy seeing you here, Professor McGonagall."

16.content:
He turned to smile at the tabby, but it had gone. Instead he was smiling
at a rather severe-looking woman who was wearing square glasses exactly
the shape of the markings the cat had had around its eyes. She, too, was
wearing a cloak, an emerald one. Her black hair was drawn into a tight
bun. She looked distinctly ruffled.
"How did you know it was me?" she asked.
"My dear Professor, I 've never seen a cat sit so stiffly."
"You'd be stiff if you'd been sitting on a brick wall all day," said
Professor McGonagall.
"All day? When you could have been celebrating? I must have passed a
dozen feasts and parties on my way here."
Professor McGonagall sniffed angrily.

16.grade5: A man turned to smile at the cat, but it was gone. Instead he was smiling at a woman who looked very serious. She had square glasses that matched the shape of the cat's eyes. She wore a green cloak and her black hair was tied up in a tight bun. She looked upset.

17.content:
"Oh yes, everyone's celebrating, all right," she said impatiently.
"You'd think they'd be a bit more careful, but no -- even the Muggles
have noticed something's going on. It was on their news." She jerked her
head back at the Dursleys' dark living-room window. "I heard it. Flocks
of owls... shooting stars.... Well, they're not completely stupid. They
were bound to notice something. Shooting stars down in Kent -- I'll bet
that was Dedalus Diggle. He never had much sense."
"You can't blame them," said Dumbledore gently. "We've had precious
little to celebrate for eleven years."
"I know that," said Professor McGonagall irritably. "But that's no
reason to lose our heads. People are being downright careless, out on
the streets in broad daylight, not even dressed in Muggle clothes,
swapping rumors."
She threw a sharp, sideways glance at Dumbledore here, as though hoping
he was going to tell her something, but he didn't, so she went on. "A
fine thing it would be if, on the very day YouKnow-Who seems to have
disappeared at last, the Muggles found out about us all. I suppose he
really has gone, Dumbledore?"

17.grade5: Everyone was excited, but she wasn't happy about it. She thought they should be more careful, even though the Muggles noticed something strange happening. It happened on their news. She heard that owls and shooting stars were seen in Kent. She thinks it might have been Dedalus Diggle, who isn't very smart. You can't blame people for being excited because we haven't had anything to celebrate in a long time. But some people are being too careless and talking about things they shouldn't be. They're even wearing their Muggle clothes outside during the day! She looked at Dumbledore and hoped he would tell her something, but he didn't. So she kept talking. If the bad guy has really disappeared, it's not good that the Muggles found out about us. Maybe he really did leave for good.

18.content:
"It certainly seems so," said Dumbledore. "We have much to be thankful
for. Would you care for a lemon drop?"
"A what?"
"A lemon drop. They're a kind of Muggle sweet I'm rather fond of"
"No, thank you," said Professor McGonagall coldly, as though she didn't
think this was the moment for lemon drops. "As I say, even if
You-Know-Who has gone -"
"My dear Professor, surely a sensible person like yourself can call him
by his name? All this 'You- Know-Who' nonsense -- for eleven years I
have been trying to persuade people to call him by his proper name:
Voldemort." Professor McGonagall flinched, but Dumbledore, who was
unsticking two lemon drops, seemed not to notice. "It all gets so
confusing if we keep saying 'You-Know-Who.' I have never seen any reason
to be frightened of saying Voldemort's name.
"I know you haven 't, said Professor McGonagall, sounding half
exasperated, half admiring. "But you're different. Everyone knows you're
the only one You-Know- oh, all right, Voldemort, was frightened of."
"You flatter me," said Dumbledore calmly. "Voldemort had powers I will
never have."

18.grade5: Dumbledore said, 'It seems we have a lot to be thankful for.' He offered her a lemon drop. 'What's that?' she asked. 'A lemon drop,' he replied. 'They're a type of candy I like.' She declined, and Professor McGonagall said, 'Not now, thank you.' Dumbledore started talking about Voldemort again. 'Why do we keep calling him You-Know-Who?' he asked. 'I don't see why we should be scared to say his real name,' he said. Professor McGonagall looked at him with a mix of frustration and respect. 'You're different, sir,' she said. 'Everyone knows you're the only one who's afraid of him.' Dumbledore smiled and said, 'You're being kind, but I'm not afraid like others are. Voldemort had powers that I'll never have.'

19.content:
"Only because you're too -- well -- noble to use them."
"It's lucky it's dark. I haven't blushed so much since Madam Pomfrey
told me she liked my new earmuffs."
Professor McGonagall shot a sharp look at Dumbledore and said, "The owls
are nothing next to the rumors that are flying around. You know what
everyone's saying? About why he's disappeared? About what finally
stopped him?"
It seemed that Professor McGonagall had reached the point she was most
anxious to discuss, the real reason she had been waiting on a cold, hard
wall all day, for neither as a cat nor as a woman had she fixed
Dumbledore with such a piercing stare as she did now. It was plain that
whatever "everyone" was saying, she was not going to believe it until
Dumbledore told her it was true. Dumbledore, however, was choosing
another lemon drop and did not answer.
"What they're saying," she pressed on, "is that last night Voldemort
turned up in Godric's Hollow. He went to find the Potters. The rumor is
that Lily and James Potter are -- are -- that they're -- dead. "
Dumbledore bowed his head. Professor McGonagall gasped.

20.content:
"Lily and James... I can't believe it... I didn't want to believe it...
Oh, Albus..."
Dumbledore reached out and patted her on the shoulder. "I know... I
know..." he said heavily.
Professor McGonagall's voice trembled as she went on. "That's not all.
They're saying he tried to kill the Potter's son, Harry. But -- he
couldn't. He couldn't kill that little boy. No one knows why, or how,
but they're saying that when he couldn't kill Harry Potter, Voldemort's
power somehow broke -- and that's why he's gone.
Dumbledore nodded glumly.
"It's -- it's true?" faltered Professor McGonagall. "After all he's
done... all the people he's killed... he couldn't kill a little boy?
It's just astounding... of all the things to stop him... but how in the
name of heaven did Harry survive?"
"We can only guess," said Dumbledore. "We may never know."

21.content:
Professor McGonagall pulled out a lace handkerchief and dabbed at her
eyes beneath her spectacles. Dumbledore gave a great sniff as he took a
golden watch from his pocket and examined it. It was a very odd watch.
It had twelve hands but no numbers; instead, little planets were moving
around the edge. It must have made sense to Dumbledore, though, because
he put it back in his pocket and said, "Hagrid's late. I suppose it was
he who told you I'd be here, by the way?"
"Yes," said Professor McGonagall. "And I don't suppose you're going to
tell me why you're here, of all places?"
"I've come to bring Harry to his aunt and uncle. They're the only family
he has left now."
"You don't mean -- you can't mean the people who live here?" cried
Professor McGonagall, jumping to her feet and pointing at number four.
"Dumbledore -- you can't. I've been watching them all day. You couldn't
find two people who are less like us. And they've got this son -- I saw
him kicking his mother all the way up the street, screaming for sweets.
Harry Potter come and live here!"

He must have understood what it meant, because he put it back in his pocket and said, 'Hagrid is late. I suppose he told you I'd be here, by the way.'

22.content:
"It's the best place for him," said Dumbledore firmly. "His aunt and
uncle will be able to explain everything to him when he's older. I've
written them a letter."
"A letter?" repeated Professor McGonagall faintly, sitting back down on
the wall. "Really, Dumbledore, you think you can explain all this in a
letter? These people will never understand him! He'll be famous -- a
legend -- I wouldn't be surprised if today was known as Harry Potter day
in the future -- there will be books written about Harry -- every child
in our world will know his name!"
"Exactly," said Dumbledore, looking very seriously over the top of his
half-moon glasses. "It would be enough to turn any boy's head. Famous
before he can walk and talk! Famous for something he won't even
remember! CarA you see how much better off he'll be, growing up away
from all that until he's ready to take it?"

23.content:
Professor McGonagall opened her mouth, changed her mind, swallowed, and
then said, "Yes -- yes, you're right, of course. But how is the boy
getting here, Dumbledore?" She eyed his cloak suddenly as though she
thought he might be hiding Harry underneath it.
"Hagrid's bringing him."
"You think it -- wise -- to trust Hagrid with something as important as
this?"
I would trust Hagrid with my life," said Dumbledore.
"I'm not saying his heart isn't in the right place," said Professor
McGonagall grudgingly, "but you can't pretend he's not careless. He does
tend to -- what was that?"
A low rumbling sound had broken the silence around them. It grew
steadily louder as they looked up and down the street for some sign of a
headlight; it swelled to a roar as they both looked up at the sky -- and
a huge motorcycle fell out of the air and landed on the road in front of
them.

24.content:
If the motorcycle was huge, it was nothing to the man sitting astride
it. He was almost twice as tall as a normal man and at least five times
as wide. He looked simply too big to be allowed, and so wild - long
tangles of bushy black hair and beard hid most of his face, he had hands
the size of trash can lids, and his feet in their leather boots were
like baby dolphins. In his vast, muscular arms he was holding a bundle
of blankets.
"Hagrid," said Dumbledore, sounding relieved. "At last. And where did
you get that motorcycle?"
"Borrowed it, Professor Dumbledore, sit," said the giant, climbing
carefully off the motorcycle as he spoke. "Young Sirius Black lent it to
me. I've got him, sir."
"No problems, were there?"
"No, sir -- house was almost destroyed, but I got him out all right
before the Muggles started swarmin' around. He fell asleep as we was
flyin' over Bristol."
Dumbledore and Professor McGonagall bent forward over the bundle of
blankets. Inside, just visible, was a baby boy, fast asleep. Under a
tuft of jet-black hair over his forehead they could see a curiously
shaped cut, like a bolt of lightning.

24.grade5: If the motorcycle was really big, it didn't seem that impressive to the man sitting on it. He was almost twice as tall as a normal person and at least five times wider. He looked too big to be allowed, and his wild hair and beard made him look even more intimidating. His hands were huge, like trash can lids, and his feet in their boots looked like baby dolphins. The man had a big bundle of blankets in his massive arms.

25.content:
"Is that where -?" whispered Professor McGonagall.
"Yes," said Dumbledore. "He'll have that scar forever."
"Couldn't you do something about it, Dumbledore?"
"Even if I could, I wouldn't. Scars can come in handy. I have one myself
above my left knee that is a perfect map of the London Underground. Well
-- give him here, Hagrid -- we'd better get this over with."
Dumbledore took Harry in his arms and turned toward the Dursleys' house.
"Could I -- could I say good-bye to him, sir?" asked Hagrid. He bent his
great, shaggy head over Harry and gave him what must have been a very
scratchy, whiskery kiss. Then, suddenly, Hagrid let out a howl like a
wounded dog.
"Shhh!" hissed Professor McGonagall, "you'll wake the Muggles!"
"S-s-sorry," sobbed Hagrid, taking out a large, spotted handkerchief and
burying his face in it. "But I c-c-can't stand it -- Lily an' James dead
-- an' poor little Harry off ter live with Muggles -"

25.grade5: One day, Professor McGonagall whispered to Dumbledore, 'Is that where he is?' Dumbledore replied, 'Yes, he'll always have that scar.' 'Can't you do something about it, Dumbledore?' someone asked. 'Even if I could, I wouldn't,' said Dumbledore. 'Scars can be helpful sometimes. I have one too - a map of the London Underground above my knee.' Dumbledore then took Harry in his arms and walked towards the Dursleys' house. Hagrid asked if he could say goodbye to Harry. As Hagrid bent down to kiss him, he let out a loud howl like a hurt dog. 'Shh!' Professor McGonagall whispered, 'Don't wake up the neighbors!' Hagrid apologized and covered his face with a big handkerchief. He was very sad because his friends Lily and James had died, and Harry had to live with Muggles now.

26.content:
"Yes, yes, it's all very sad, but get a grip on yourself, Hagrid, or
we'll be found," Professor McGonagall whispered, patting Hagrid gingerly
on the arm as Dumbledore stepped over the low garden wall and walked to
the front door. He laid Harry gently on the doorstep, took a letter out
of his cloak, tucked it inside Harry's blankets, and then came back to
the other two. For a full minute the three of them stood and looked at
the little bundle; Hagrid's shoulders shook, Professor McGonagall
blinked furiously, and the twinkling light that usually shone from
Dumbledore's eyes seemed to have gone out.
"Well," said Dumbledore finally, "that's that. We've no business staying
here. We may as well go and join the celebrations."
"Yeah," said Hagrid in a very muffled voice, "I'll be takin' Sirius his
bike back. G'night, Professor McGonagall -- Professor Dumbledore, sir."
Wiping his streaming eyes on his jacket sleeve, Hagrid swung himself
onto the motorcycle and kicked the engine into life; with a roar it rose
into the air and off into the night.

27.content:
"I shall see you soon, I expect, Professor McGonagall," said Dumbledore,
nodding to her. Professor McGonagall blew her nose in reply.
Dumbledore turned and walked back down the street. On the corner he
stopped and took out the silver Put-Outer. He clicked it once, and
twelve balls of light sped back to their street lamps so that Privet
Drive glowed suddenly orange and he could make out a tabby cat slinking
around the corner at the other end of the street. He could just see the
bundle of blankets on the step of number four.
"Good luck, Harry," he murmured. He turned on his heel and with a swish
of his cloak, he was gone.

28.content:
A breeze ruffled the neat hedges of Privet Drive, which lay silent and
tidy under the inky sky, the very last place you would expect
astonishing things to happen. Harry Potter rolled over inside his
blankets without waking up. One small hand closed on the letter beside
him and he slept on, not knowing he was special, not knowing he was
famous, not knowing he would be woken in a few hours' time by Mrs.
Dursley's scream as she opened the front door to put out the milk
bottles, nor that he would spend the next few weeks being prodded and
pinched by his cousin Dudley... He couldn't know that at this very
moment, people meeting in secret all over the country were holding up
their glasses and saying in hushed voices: "To Harry Potter -- the boy
who lived!"
